abstract.t: The Path Computation Element (PCE) provides functions of path computation in support of traffic engineering (TE) in Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) and Generalized MPLS (GMPLS) networks.

When a Path Computation Client (PCC) requests a PCE for a route, it may request a specific amount of bandwidth for a TE LSP. Protocol support for this capability is described in , which defines BANDWIDTH object for this purpose.

Unfortunately the definition provided therein does not allow the object to be extended to carry information and semantics necessary to cover requirements in GMPLS deployments. This document describes a mechanism which can be used by peers participating in a PCEP session to agree on using an extensible definition of BANDWIDTH.

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Introduction
section.t: describes the Path Computation Element Protocol PCEP. PCEP defines the communication between a Path Computation Client (PCC) and a Path Control Element (PCE), or between PCE and PCE, enabling computation of Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) for Traffic Engineering Label Switched Path (TE LSP) characteristics.

specifies a set of extensions to PCEP to enable its use in GMPLS networks. It defines a set of new objects which provide introduce new variations of concepts already defined in . It then rolls up message definitions on all currently known drafts and RFCs, replacing their use of the non-generalized objects with the generalized ones.

This document describes an alternative approach, which works by allowing peers to negotiate the use of an updated defintion of BANDWIDTH object and its on-wire format, which meet requirements set out in .

section.title: Capability Negotiation
section.t: During PCEP Initialization Phase, PCEP Speakers (PCE or PCC) have to negotiate the use of this extension. A PCEP speaker includes the "Generalized Bandwidth Capability" TLV, described in . The TLV contains a set of flags, which indicate the speaker's support for asymmetric bandwidth and which Traffic Specification are supported by the advertizing peer.
The presence of the Generalized Bandwidth Capability TLV in a speaker's OPEN Object indicates that the speaker is willing to use the BANDWIDTH object definition specified in this document.
The PCEP protocol extensions for generalized bandwidth object MUST NOT be used if one or both PCEP speakers have not included the Generalized Bandwidth Capability TLV in its OPEN object.

section.title: Generalized Bandwidth Capability TLV
section.t: The format of the GENERALIZED-BANDWIDTH-CAPABILITY TLV is shown in the following figure:

The value comprises a single field - Flags (32 bits).
If set to 1 by a speaker, the A flag indicates, that the speaker supports asymmetric bandwidth specification.
If set to 1 by a speaker, the I flag indicates, that the speaker supports specification of Intserv traffic specification as defined by .
If set to 1 by a speaker, the S flag indicates, that the speaker supports specification of SONET/SDH traffic specification as defined by .
If set to 1 by a speaker, the G flag indicates, that the speaker supports specification of G.709 traffic specification as defined by .
If set to 1 by a speaker, the E flag indicates, that the speaker supports specification of Ethernet traffic specification as defined by .
Unassigned bits are considered reserved. They MUST be set to 0 on transmission and MUST be ignored on receipt.

section.title: BANDWIDTH Object
section.t: Object header of BANDWIDTH object is kept intact in its definition. The object's length can be variable. Object payload format depends on the value of ASYMMETRIC-BANDWIDTH-CAPABILITY bit: if the value is 0, then the unidirectional format is used, otherwise the bidirectional format is used.

section.title: Unidirectional BANDWIDTH Object
section.t: The Unidirectional format of BANDWIDTH object is as follows:

Traffic specification in the forward direction.
Optional TLVs may be included within the object to extend the information conveyed by it. The specification of such TLVs is outside the scope of this document.

section.title: Bidirectional BANDWIDTH Object
section.t: The Bidirectional format of BANDWIDTH object is as follows:

Traffic specification along the forward direction of the LSP.
Traffic specification along the reverse direction of the LSP.
Optional TLVs may be included within the BANDWIDTH object body to extend the information conveyed by the object. The specification of such TLVs is outside the scope of this document.

section.title: PCEP-BANDWIDTH Object
section.t: This document defines a new format and semantics of PCEP-BANDWIDTH Object. These are a strict superset of original semantics.
